answerText: "Drinking Alone by Moonlight" [or "Drinking Alone Beneath the Moon"; or a bunch of other English translations that convey that drinking is being done by oneself besides a moon; or "Yue xia du zhuo"][10] "Drinking Alone by Moonlight" is a poem by this Tang Dynasty drunkard, who was slightly younger than Du Fu and reportedly drowned in an attempt to grab the reflection of the moon on a lake.
heading: ACF Regionals  |2012 | Yale A | 3 | Literature | World | College
subject: Literature
question: Question: This poem ends with the hope that "one day we may truly meet in the far misty heavens." For 10 points each: [10] Name this poem in which the poet and his shadow are joined in a celebration by a celestial body, to whom the poet raises his cup.
